Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Georgia is to develop a platform for antibody mimetics by scaffolding peptides on single stranded DNA. This award is cofunded by the Genetic Mechanisms program in the Division of Molecular & Cellular Biosciences in the Directorate for Biological Sciences. Antibodies are essential to facilitating discoveries in biomedical research; however, they have a variety of shortcomings that have elicited concerns over accessibility to high-quality antibodies for biomedical research. Alterative and more robust polymers for molecular recognition are needed to drive discovery efforts forward. Nucleic acid polymers have demonstrated immense promise as high-affinity reagents; however, their lack of chemical functionality limits their ability to compete with proteins as receptors. By merging the evolvable molecular scaffold of nucleic acid polymers with diverse protein functionality, the PI aims to evolve a new class of antibody mimetics for biomedical research, which may address the critical deficit of available antibodies for molecular targets. These research efforts will be coupled with educational and training outreach at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels in order to assist in the development of a future generation of scientists that are properly equipped to tackle interdisciplinary research problems.


Technical: This proposal describes research to develop an in vitro selection platform for antibody mimetics by scaffolding peptides on DNA. Nucleic acid aptamers have provided numerous advantages over traditional antibodies; however, their functional group deficit limits their potential to match the performance of proteinogenic affinity reagents. By merging the evolvable molecular scaffold of nucleic acid polymers with protein functionality, this investigator will use this class of polymers to mimic the hetero- and multivalent approach nature uses at protein-protein interfaces. The investigator will use an enzymatic strategy to sequence-specifically incorporate unique peptide fragments along a DNA template. This approach will enable the concomitant evolution of the ssDNA scaffold and the identity of the displayed peptides to achieve molecular recognition of protein targets. If successful, this new class of biomimetic polymers could aid in addressing the deficit of high-affinity reagents for biomedical research. These research efforts will be coupled with educational and training outreach at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical diversity enables enhanced molecular function, be it form of molecular recognition or catalysis. Not surprisingly, nature places proteins, which are rich in chemical diversity, at the apogee of cellular control. Conversely, DNA, which is limited to four canonical bases, is largely employed as information storage. Notwithstanding, DNA can readily fold into complex three-dimensional shapes when in single-stranded form. Since DNA can be rapidly replicated and mutated, DNA can be evolved in the lab to have many of the functions of proteins, from binding to proteins and small molecules to catalyzing chemical reactions. However, the scope and efficiency of DNA as a functional biopolymer is limited by its dearth of functional groups. Scientists have speculated that increasing the chemical diversity of DNA would likely enhance its functional capacity. Indeed, recent reports have demonstrated that the incorporation of small molecules through a DNA polymer can enhance its binding and catalytic function. The importance of developing DNA-based biopolymers with molecular recognition or catalytic properties is rooted in their use as antibody mimetics for medical diagnostics of human disease and tools for biological applications

The primary goal of this project was to develop new technologies to sequence-specifically incorporate peptide fragments onto a DNA scaffold. Such DNA-scaffolded peptides could then be evolved for desired function. Throughout these funded studies, we have demonstrated that specific DNA ligases are able to sequence-specifically incorporate short DNA fragments (5 bases long) that carry a peptide fragment up to eight amino acids in length. We further demonstrated that the DNA-scaffolded peptides can be read by specific polymerases to enable evolution cycles for molecular function. This new class of DNA-scaffolded polymers exhibit unique properties, such as greater stability at higher temperatures. Lastly, we have shown that up to 32 unique peptide fragments can be incorporated throughout a DNA scaffold, enabling the evolution of both the DNA sequence and the combinatorial display of the peptide sequence. These results demonstrate the potential of DNA-scaffolded peptides to be evolved for molecular recognition and catalysis. The project has also provided training to undergraduate and graduate students, including five undergraduates and three graduate students, all of whom have continued on to pursue careers in STEM. Further to this, advising of the student affiliates of the American Chemical Society, and supervision and training of the chemistry badge for the Boy Scouts of America was provided throughout the year during the term of the award.
